ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Thematic knowledge on Japanese cultural topics (education, friendship, history, etc) and acquisition of new grammatical structures. Lots of practice speaking and discussing our ideas in writing. Lots of exposure to new ways to engage with Japanese language (music, stories, books, TV shows, movies, topics).
A lot of practical Japanese ability and skills to use, although many were less focused on daily life and more focused on specific niches.

We practiced our skills utilizing Japanese in nearly all contexts - writing, conversation, presentations, reading, watching films - while also developing a more complex vocabulary to discuss world issues.
Japanese, debate, talking about difficult issues, and more
I learned how to read and write more. I learned how to think & communicate ideas. I learned a lot about Japanese society too.
We read several short stories and watched some movies/drama episodes, which I think were great ways to expand vocabulary and learn new grammatical constructions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I would have liked a deeper focus on more commonly used Japanese (ie. daily life) instead of delving into more specific topics like AI which are difficult enough to speak about in English.

The classes were very well paced and lively, and I feel that it truly was the challenge that I needed to improve my Japanese. Although the workload was very significant, and possibly should be lessened a bit, I think it paid off for all of us.

The material that we were taught was interesting. I liked how there were different media for assignments (e.g. movies, short story readings, videos, etc) so we never got tired of doing the same thing over and over again. I think personally, I would like to have more reading assignments, just so that I can learn kanji more efficiently.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Nishimura sensei is the best professor in the Japanese department and her dedication shows through both the countless hours she spends for her students and the late nights she is up occupied with Japanese related tasks.
I would recommend this course to another student because they can learn a lot, and it is also very fun.
For those interested in learning more Japanese, yes. The class is small and encourages engagement and the kinds of media and literature discussed were all very interesting.
